He feels suffocated by the expectations to be clean, proper and regimented - the hogshead represents freedom from societal constraints. It symbolizes how Huck yearns for the simplicity and autonomy of his earlier rough-and-tumble existence compared to the stuffy conventionality imposed on him now. His staunch refusal to rejoin that life, even at Tom’s urging, underscores Huck’s core self-reliance and how he rages against domestication.
